frameDefinitions: An Assailant physically attacks a Victim (which is usually but not always sentient), causing or intending to cause the Victim physical damage.

An Assailant, a group of armed forces, surrounds the Victim, a military location and the people within it, in an attempt to cut the Victim off from the outside, with the goal of either forcing their surrender or weakening them so that an invasion would be successful.
An Patient, which is an organic substance, undergoes the natural process of decay due to a Cause (or Agent).
An Assailant physically attacks a Victim (which is usually but not always sentient), causing or intending to cause the Victim physical damage.
A Winner has victory over an Loser.
A New filler occupies a Role or serves a Function after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: As soon as he stepped out of the bar he was <t>set</t> upon by four men in ski-masks.
Towards the end of the summer, a great English host <t>besieged</t> the Danish fort of Tempsford and took it, killing the last Danish king of East Anglia.
Are we <t>counterattacking</t> them just to keep them off balance?
listRoleDefinitions: This role is the being or entity that is injured by the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.

The <fen>Assailant</fen> is a group of armed forces (or, metonymically, their commander or the organization they represent) that encircles, surrounds, or otherwise cuts off the Beseiged in an attempt to force surrender.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the fortification or geopolitical entity that is being attacked.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally brings about the decay of the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Patient</fen> undergoes decay.
An event which causes the <fen>Patient</fen> to rot.
The time at which the Cause causes the <fex name='Patient'>Patient</fex> to rot.
The location at which the <fen>Cause</fen> acts upon the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role is the being or entity that is injured by the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is responding to a prior attack by attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The individual or individuals who beat the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The individual or individuals that get beat by the <fen>Winner</fen>.
When the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory over the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory <fen>Loser</fen>.
The new filler of the <fen>Role</fen> that was previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen> filler.
The category that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities fit into as a result of the <fen>Function</fen> they serve.
The (generally desirable) state of affairs that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities are involved in bringing about.
The entity that occupied the <fen>Role</fen> or served the <fen>Function</fen> before the <fen>New</fen> filler.
The time at which the <fen>New</fen> takes up the <fen>Role</fen> previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The mysterious fighter attacked <fex>the guardsmen</fex> with a sabre.
<fex>The mysterious fighter</fex> attacked the guardsmen with a sabre.
<fex>As soon as he stepped out of the bar</fex> he was set upon by four men in ski-masks.
Then Jon-O's forces ambushed them <fex>on the left flank</fex> from a line of low hills.
US troopscounterattacked <fex>the French</fex> the next day.
<fex>The mysterious fighter</fex> counterattacked the guardsmen with a sabre.
<fex>The previous day's</fex> counterattack on French troops was deemed a success.
Then they staged a counterattack<fex>on our left flank</fex>.
The traditional thatched roof has often been replaced <fex>by corrugated galvanized iron</fex>.
What gas replaced Hydrogen <fex>as a safer medium for use in balloons</fex> on account it does not burn?
Oil and gas replaced coal <fex>in heating homes, in industry, and in transportation</fex>.
The electron was discovered and <fex>electricity</fex> replaced gas lamps.
When electricity replaced oil <fex>in the early 1930's</fex>, the steady beam was replaced by a flashing light.

passageCandidateSpans.text: the Second Battle of the Marne

the Second Battle of the Marne
